title: Sukkah
text: Mishnah: A sukkah that is taller than twenty amos is invalid. Rabbi Yehudah permits it.
Or if it is less than ten tefachim tall, or if it does not have (three) walls, or if it has more sunlight than shade, it is invalid.
Gemara: It is taught in a Mishnah there: A mavoi that is taller than twenty amos must be lowered. Rabbi Yehuda says: It is not necessary.
What is the difference between a sukkah, that was taught to be invalid, and a mavoi, that was taught to be repaired?
Sukkah is a Torah commandment, so it was taught to be invalid. Mavoi is a rabbinic commandment, so it was taught to be repaired.

And if you need, I could say: [In the case of a] Torah commandments it could have also been taught to repair it. Nonetheless, [the ruling for] sukkah (containing many statements), was given concisely, and taught that it is invalid. [The ruling for] mavoi, which does not contain many statements, taught to repair it.

Rabbah said: As it says in the Torah: (Leviticus 23:43) "In order that your generations will know that I settled the children of Israel in sukkot." Until twenty amos, a person knows that he is dwelling in a sukkah. Above twenty amos, a person does not know that he is dwelling in a sukkah, because it is not in his field of vision.

Rabbi Zeira said: From here: (Isaiah 4:6) "And a sukkah will be for shade from the Sun during the day." Until twenty amah, a person sits in the shade of a sukkah. Above twenty amah, a person does sit in the shade of the sukkah; rather, in the shade of its walls.
Abaye said to him: Rather, from that, whoever builds his sukkah in Ashteroth Karnayim, this also would not be a sukkah!
He said to him: There, remove Ashteroth Karnayim, and there is shade from the sukkah. Here, remove the walls, and there is no shade from the sukkah.

And Rabbah says: From here: (Leviticus 23:42) "In sukkahs you will sit for seven days." The Torah said, For all seven days, leave from a permanent dwelling and dwell in a temporary dwelling. Until twenty amah, a person builds a dwelling as a temporary dwelling. Above twenty amah, a person does not build a dwelling as a temporary dwelling, rather as a permanent dwelling.
Abaye said to him: Rather, from that, someone who makes walls from iron and puts sekhakh on top, this also would not be a sukkah!

He said to him: This is what I said to you: Until twenty amah, when a person builds a dwelling, it is a temporary dwelling. If he built it as a permanent dwelling, he has still fulfilled [the mitzvah]. Above twenty amah, when a person builds a dwelling, it is a permanent dwelling. If he built it as a temporary dwelling, he has also not fulfilled [the mitzvah].
Rav Cheskiah said in the name of Rav Yermiah who said in the name of Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai: I am able to exempt the entire world of judgment.
